Table 1 shows the performance of each algorithm under the optimal hyperparameter settings. On small, medium and large datasets of MNIST, the personalized model of our algorithm outperforms other SOTA comparison algorithms by 1.25%percent\%, 1.78%percent\% and 0.52%percent\%, while the global model outperforms other SOTA models by 2.79%percent\%, 1.67%percent\% and 1.97%percent\%, respectively. We can see that our algorithm performs better when the amount of data is small, thanks to the advantage of the Bayesian algorithm on small samples.
Figure 2 shows the comparison results of the convergence speed of different algorithms on the MNIST dataset. We can see that our pFedBayes converges significantly under a small dataset, and the performance is stable after 50 iterations, clearly ahead of other algorithms.

We test pFedBayes in a basic DNN model with 3 full connection layers [784, 100, 10] on the MNIST dataset. The results are listed in Table 2.
Effects of η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1} and η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2}: In pFedBayes algorithm, η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1} and η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2} are respectively denote the learning rate of the personalized model and global model. We tune the learning rate in the range of [0.001,0.005]0.0010.005[0.001,0.005] while fix other parameters. From Table 2 we can see that η1=η2=0.001subscript𝜂1subscript𝜂20.001\eta_{1}=\eta_{2}=0.001 is the best setting. Effects of ζ𝜁\zeta: In pFedBayes algorithm, ζ𝜁\zeta can adjust the degree of personalization of personalized models. Increasing ζ𝜁\zeta can improve the test accuracy of the global model and weaken the performance of the personalized model. On the basis of the best learning rate, we tune ζ∈{0.5,1,5,10,20}𝜁0.5151020\zeta\in\{0.5,1,5,10,20\}. Table 2 shows that ζ=10𝜁10\zeta=10 is the best setting. Hence, we set ζ=10𝜁10\zeta=10 for the remaining experiments. Effects of ρ𝜌\rho: It is known that the initialization of the weight parameters affects the results of the model. Hence, we also tune ρ∈{−1,−1.5,−2,−2.5,−3}𝜌11.522.53\rho\in\{-1,-1.5,-2,-2.5,-3\}. Table 2 shows that ρ=−2.5𝜌2.5\rho=-2.5 is the best setting. Hence, we set ρ=−2.5𝜌2.5\rho=-2.5 for the remaining experiments.

references: The results of FedAvg, Fedprox, NBFed, Per-FedAvg, pFedMe, HeurFedAMP and pFedGP are listed in Table 3. The parameters η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1} and η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2} are the learning rates of the personalized model and the global model, respectively. “Personalized” means this column indicates whether this is a personalized algorithm. In order to make a fair comparison with these algorithms, we perform the following hyperparameter adjustment. In (T Dinh et al., 2020), λ=15𝜆15\lambda=15 achieves the best performance and is the recommended setting, so we use this setting directly in our experiments. We tune λ∈{0.001,0.01,0.1,1}𝜆0.0010.010.11\lambda\in\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1\} the same as the setting in Fedprox (Li et al., 2018). For HeurFedAMP , we tune α∈[0.1,0.5]𝛼0.10.5\alpha\in[0.1,0.5], and 0.50.50.5 is the recommended setting in its paper (Huang et al., 2021). For pFedGP, the recommended learning rate in its paper is 0.05, we hence tune η∈[0.01,0.05,0.1]𝜂0.010.050.1\eta\in[0.01,0.05,0.1]. We can see that η=0.05𝜂0.05\eta=0.05 can achieve better performance. For other hyperparameters in pFedGP, we set them the same as in (Achituve et al., 2021). Notably, α𝛼\alpha represents the proportion of the client model that does not interact with the global model. The higher the value, the less interaction with the global model. For other algorithms, there are 10 client models interacting with the global model. For a fair comparison, the corresponding α𝛼\alpha should be set to 0.1. Clearly 0.5 provides better performance of the personalized model, although a setting of 0.5 is not a fair comparison. We still use the parameter setting of 0.5 recommended in its paper. In addition, it should be noted that the learning rate cannot be set too large, and an appropriate value should be taken. For most federated learning algorithms, a learning rate that is too large will cause the model to diverge, resulting in a severe loss of model aggregation performance. From the experimental results of the personalized algorithms, we find that the optimal learning rate is between 0.0005 and 0.01. For a fair comparison, we also set the learning rates of the non-personalized algorithms, i.e. FedAvg and FedProx, within this range.
